content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, the strategy that maximizes my total earnings over 75 rounds depends on my assumptions about the opponent's behavior. If I assume that the opponent is acting randomly or without a strategy, then picking R would be more profitable in the long run because it gives a higher reward (45$) when matched with R and only a slightly lower reward (20$) when matched with B compared to the opponent getting 40$ when they pick B while I choose R.

However, if I believe that my opponent has a strategy based on the game's structure and might be more likely to respond with R when I choose R and B when I choose B, then it would make sense to mix up my choices between R and B to avoid being predictable and take advantage of the situations where my opponent chooses R while I choose B.

In either case, it is difficult to know for sure what the optimal strategy is without more information about the opponent's behavior, so it might be wise to play a mix of both R and B in different proportions depending on the specific circumstances and observations during the gameplay. Therefore, my choice would be curly bracket{R or B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this particular scenario where I chose B and my opponent chose R, it seems that choosing R in the next round could result in a higher payoff since my opponent is more likely to respond with R as well, given their previous choice. However, it's important to remember that the optimal strategy may still involve mixing up choices between R and B, especially if we don't know whether our opponent will adapt their strategy based on my initial choice in this round.

So, in the next round, I would choose curly bracket{R or B} with a slight bias towards R to exploit the advantage of having chosen R in the previous round and potentially maximize my payoff.
